text: One group of feldspar minerals contains potassium ions in its structure and is therefore referred to as potassium feldspar .
Despite these differences , all feldspar minerals have similar physical properties .
Potassium feldspar is usually light cream , salmon pink , or occasionally blue-green in color .
Striations are found on some cleavage planes of plagioclase feldspar but are not present on potassium feldspar .
The plagioclase feldspars , on the other hand , range in color from white to medium gray .
As a component in igneous rocks , feldspar crystals can be identified by their rectangular shape and rather smooth , shiny faces .
The other group , called plagioclase feldspar , contains both sodium and calcium ions that freely substitute for one another , depending on the environment during crystallization .
The only way to distinguish the feldspars physically is to look for a multitude of fine parallel lines , called striations .
They have two planes of cleavage meeting at or near 90-degree angles , are relatively hard ( 6 on the Mohs scale ) , and have a luster that ranges from glassy to pearly .
However , color should not be used to distinguish these groups .
